Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: RÉFLEXIONS SUR LA TOLÉRANCE
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR S.A.
Issue: i40182096
Date: 1 1, 1994
Author(s): BONHÔTE FRANÇOISE
Abstract: La notion de tolérance est problématique: je m'efforce de le montrer en considérant tout d'abord les critiques dont elle est ou a été la cible. Puis, en partant de la conception de Locke, je relève les dilemmes qui peuvent surgir de la mise en pratique de la tolérance et la nécessité, mais aussi la difficulté, de fixer les limites de son application. Corollaire de la liberté de pensée et de l'acceptation du pluralisme, la tolérance est décrite, en dernier lieu, comme mise à l'épreuve purificatrice de nos convictions et comme instauratrice d'une véritable relation de réciprocité dans la mesure où elle parvient à dépasser le simple acquiescement à la diversité. The concept of tolerance is problematic : this I try to show first by considering the criticisms made of it. Then, starting with the perception of Locke, I point out the potential dilemmas of practising tolerance and the need, as well as the difficulty, of fixing limits to tolerance. A corollary to the freedom of thought and the approbation of pluralism, tolerance is finally described as the refining proof of conviction and the instigator of true reciprocity to the degree that it goes beyond the simple acquiescence of diversity.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44357469 journal-article-10.2307_44357469.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: CORPS ET TRANSCENDANCE: Une mise en relation dans "Le volontaire et l'involontaire" de Paul Ricœur
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR S.A.
Issue: i40182104
Date: 1 1, 1995
Author(s): Jacques Robert
Abstract: Dans le contexte des recherches actuelles sur le corps, cet article souligne la fécondité du dialogue engagé par P. Ricœur entre les savoirs objectifs et la phénoménologie dans la description des rapports de la nature et de la liberté. Cette conversation dessine une mise en relation originale entre l'existence corporelle et la Transcendance; elle invite à reconnaître dans la corporéité le lieu d'incarnation d'une confiance primordiale. In the context of current research on the body, this articles underlines the rich dialogue begun by P. Ricœur between the objective sciences and phenomenology on the connection between nature and freedom. This dialogue establishes an original link between corporal existence and transcendence; it invites us to see corporality as the incarnation of a primordial trust.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44357878 journal-article-10.2307_44357878.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: L'UTILISATION PHILOSOPHIQUE DE LA MÉTAPHORE EN GRÈCE ET EN CHINE: Vers une métaphorologie comparée
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR S.A.
Issue: i40182113
Date: 1 1, 1997
Author(s): Reding Jean-Paul
Abstract: Tout porte à croire qu'une langue «exotique» donne naissance également à des métaphores exotiques, qui conditionnent à leur tour des modes de penser différents des nôtres. L'analyse comparée d'un champ métaphorique commun à la Grèce et à la Chine (la lumière et le miroir) montre que les différences philosophiques ne procèdent pas de la diversité matérielle des métaphores utilisées, mais bien plutôt d'attitudes différentes adoptées face au langage. L'hypothèse du relativisme linguistique, loin de pouvoir être infirmée ou confirmée à travers l'analyse comparée, apparaît elle-même comme étant déjà dépendante de la manière dont la pensée grecque et occidentale a conçu les rapports entre la pensée et le langage. Everything leads us to believe that an «exotic» language produces exotic metaphors, which in turn condition those modesof thought different from our own. Comparative analysis of a metaphorical field common to Greece and China (light and the mirror) shows that the philosophical differences do not proceeed from the various material of the metaphors used, but rather from the different attitudes to language. The hypothesis of linguistic relativism far from being either weakened or confirmed by this comparative analysis, appears itself to depend on the manner in which Greek and occidental thought conceived the relation of thought to language.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44358278 journal-article-10.2307_44358278.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: UTILITARISME ET CHRISTIANISME : UNE TRIPLE MISE EN PERSPECTIVE
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR S.A.
Issue: i40182120
Date: 1 1, 1998
Author(s): Müller Denis
Abstract: L'auteur esquisse la relation de l'utilitarisme et du christianisme sous l'angle triple des rapports entre le bien et le salut, le sacrifice et le sujet, la souffrance réduite ou affrontée. Le trépied ainsi proposé ne constitue pas une cage de fer, à laquelle toute comparaison et toute lecture devraient se soumettre ou se refuser, mais seulement une possible structure de dialogue et de débat, devant faciliter et fructifier l'interpellation réciproque de la morale utilitariste et de l'éthique chrétienne. The author sketches the link of utilitarianism and Christianity on three bases : the relation of goodness and faith ; of sacrifice and the individual, of suffering denied and suffering met. This three-legged stool is not an iron cage meant to be accepted or rejected by the reader, but only a possible framework for dialogue designed to allow the mutual questioning of utilitarian morals and Christian ethics.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44358600 journal-article-10.2307_44358600.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: RÉFLEXIONS ŒCUMÉNIQUES AUTOUR DE L'ENCYCLIQUE "UT UNUM SINT"
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR S.A.
Issue: i40182129
Date: 1 1, 1999
Author(s): Charrière Nicolas
Abstract: Jean-Paul II, dans son encyclique Ut unum sint, situe l'œcuménisme dans une double relation ascendante et descendante: d'une part relation de l'homme à Dieu et d'autre part relation de l'homme au monde. Ces deux mouvements doivent passer par la grille critique de la vérité et de l'amour pour être efficients, ce qui correspond à la Révélation comme mouvement premier de Dieu vers l'homme. Ainsi, le dialogue œcuménique ne pourra éviter une réflexion sur le statut de la vérité et de l'amour dans leur gestion ecclésiale, réflexion menée à la lumière de la polarité christologico-pneumatologique. Symptomatiquement, la question du ministère papal montre les impasses actuelles et les ouvertures possibles. John-Paul II, in his encyclical Ut unum sint, situates ecumenism in a twofold relationship, ascending and descending: the relationship of humankind to God and of humankind to the world. To be dynamic, these two movements must pass through the critical grid of truth and love, which corresponds to revelation as the first movement of God to humans. Thus ecumenical dialogue cannot avoid a reflection of the status of truth and love in ecclesiastic management, in the light of Christo-pneumatological polarity. Symptomatically, the question of papal ministry shows existing dead ends and possible apertures.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44359019 journal-article-10.2307_44359019.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: LA BIOÉTHIQUE AU PÉRIL DE DIEU POUR UNE CRITIQUE THÉOLOGIQUE DE LA MAÎTRISE ÉTHIQUE SUR LE VIVANT
Publisher: ATAR ROTO PRESSE S.A.
Issue: i40182140
Date: 1 1, 2002
Author(s): Müller Denis
Abstract: Contrairement à certains préjugés laïcistes radicaux, la question de Dieu est au cœur de l'éthique. Or les débats actuels de la bioéthique ne permettent pas toujours d'identifier clairement la pertinence de cette question. Afin de parvenir à une reformulation crédible de la contribution de l'éthique théologique à la discussion publique, il importe d'interroger les différentes manières de comprendre la relation entre les catégories d'immanence et de transcendance. En dialogue critique avec H. Tristram Engelhardt, l'auteur balise les conditions fondamentales d'accès à une interprétation de Dieu comme mystère du monde et de l'existence et donc aussi comme horizon indépassable de toute éthique. Contrary to certain radical lay prejudices, the question of God is at the heart of ethics. Yet current debates on bioethics do not always help to clearly identify the pertinence of the question. To reformulate the contribution of theological ethics to public discussion in a credible way, we must examine the different ways of understanding the relationship between immanence and transcendance. In critical dialogue with H. Tristram Engelhardt, the author marks out the basic conditions to access an interpretation of God as mystery of the world and of existance, thus also as the impassable horizon of all ethics.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44359383 journal-article-10.2307_44359383.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: L'IDENTITÉ PERSONNELLE CHEZ WITTGENSTEIN: Une approche pragmatique
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR ROTO PRESSE S.A.
Issue: i40182154
Date: 1 1, 2005
Author(s): Vezeanu Ion
Abstract: Nous montrons ici que le rejet de l'identité par Wittgenstein s'appuie sur la contestation du principe de causalité, doublé d'une conception pragmatique de la personne. Dans son rejet de la causalité la position de Wittgenstein ressemble fortement à celle de David Hume. Pour parvenir à une conception pragmatique de la personne on analysera l'usage linguistique et grammatical qui régit l'identité personnelle. Chez Wittgenstein le concept de personne se définit par rapport au contexte actionnel. Here we show that Wittgentstein's dismissal of identity is dependent on the disputing of the principle of causality, reinforced by a pragmatic concept of personhood. In his rejection of causality, the position of Wittgenstein resembles that of David Hume. In order to get to a pragmatic idea of personhood, linguistic and grammatical usage of the terms defining personal identity is analysed. For Wittgenstein, the idea of personhood is defined in relation to the actual context.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44359739 journal-article-10.2307_44359739.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: PAUL RICŒUR EN SUISSE ROMANDE: RENCONTRES, LIENS ET HÉRITAGE
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR ROTO PRESSE S.A.
Issue: i40182162
Date: 1 1, 2006
Author(s): Bonzon Syvie
Abstract: E. de Perrot, La psychothérapie de soutien, une perspective psychanalytique, Bruxelles, De Boeck, 2006, spécialement le chap. 15, «Éthique et vérité», en relation avec le débat Changeux-Ricœur, La nature et la règle, Paris, Odile Jacob, 1998.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44360039 journal-article-10.2307_44360039.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: IDENTITÉ ET SUJET DE DISCOURS: SOI-MÊME COMME LES AUTRES
Publisher: IMPRIMERIE ATAR ROTO PRESSE S.A.
Issue: i40182162
Date: 1 1, 2006
Author(s): Calame Claude
Abstract: Pour décrire les moyens dont dispose l'individu pour se constituer en personne (partagée entre l'identité du caractère, l'idem, et le soi plus personnel et moral de l 'ipse), Paul Ricœur, dans Soi-même comme un autre (Paris, Seuil 1990), emprunte aux linguistes deux ensembles conceptuels: les références identifiantes (noms propres) et les actes d'autodésignation du je. Mais, par ce double biais, la pragmatique linguistique conduirait, selon lui, à une impasse, éludant finalement la question du qui? C'est oublier que, dans l'énonciation, le je lui-même acquiert une certaine épaisseur sémantique. Une poésie mimétique d'action comme la poésie lyrique grecque montre le rôle que peut jouer dans la constitution du moi une identité énonciative collective, qui inscrit d'emblée la dialectique entre l'idem et l'ipse dans le rapport avec les autres, sans référence ni métaphysique ni théologique. To describe the means the individual has for establishing personhood (between character identity, the idem, and the more personnel and moral self of the ipse), Paul Ricoeur, in Oneself as Another (English translation 1992), borrows two conceptual ensembles from linguistics: the identifying references (proper nouns) and the self-designating acts of the self. But, according to him, by taking this double bias, linguistic pragmatics leads to an impasse by finally eluding the question "who". This is to forget that in enunciation, the very self acquires a certain semantic depth. A mimetic poetry of action, like Greek lyrical poetry, shows the role that can be played in the constitution of the self by a collectively enunciated identity, which automatically sets the dialectic between the idem and the ipse in relation to others, without metaphysical or theological reference.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44360044 journal-article-10.2307_44360044.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: L'ÂME ENTRE CORPS ET ESPRIT: Le concept husserlien de soubassement à la lumière de la phénoménologie matérielle de Michel Henry
Publisher: PCL PRESSES CENTRALES SA
Issue: i40182176
Date: 1 1, 2010
Author(s): Michel Beat
Abstract: L'œuvre de Michel Henry aura été de «recueillir» et développer le côté affectif de la phénoménologie, que Husserl, dans un passage clé de ses Idées directrices, a délaissé au profit du côté intentionnel de la subjectivité — tout comme trois siècles plus tôt Descartes avait «recueilli» la subjectivité écartée par Galilée. Le texte qui suit compare le concept de soubassement, ou âme, chez Husserl avec celui de chair chez Michel Henry. On verra que les deux philosophes parlent d'une couche sensible, qu'on peut d'une certaine manière situer entre corps et esprit, de deux points de vue diamétralement opposés. Au-delà de l'opposition entre les deux philosophies, cette recherche mène à une interprétation topologique du rapport entre corps, âme et esprit, tel que suggéré par le terme husserlien de soubassement, et propose un éclairage différent de la notion henryenne d'auto-affection. Michel Henry's objective was to "pick up" and develop the emotional side of phenomenology, which Husserl, in a key passage in Ideas, left aside in favour of the intentional side of subjectivity — just as Descartes, three centuries earlier, "picked up" subjectivity left aside by Galileo. In this article, we compare the concept of the sub-basement, or soul, for Husserl, with that of the body for Michel Henry. We will see that both philosophers speak of a sensitive layer that can be situated in a certain manner between body and spirit, from two diametrically opposite points of view. Beyond the opposition of the two philosophies, this research leads to a topological interpretation of the relation between body, soul and spirit, as suggested by Husserl's term sub-basement, and proposes a different light on Henry's notion of self-affection.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44360487 journal-article-10.2307_44360487.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: LE BIEN SUPRÊME ET LA QUESTION DE DIEU EN ÉTHIQUE: Ce que Schleiermacher peut nous donner à penser aujourd'hui
Publisher: PCL PRESSES CENTRALES SA
Issue: i40182180
Date: 1 1, 2011
Author(s): Müller Denis
Abstract: La question des rapports entre éthique philosophique et éthique théologique est au cœur de la pensée de Friedrich Daniel Schleiermacher (1768-1834). Proposant une conception originale de la raison dans ses liens à la nature et à l'histoire, l'auteur des Discours et de la Foi chrétienne restructure l'éthique philosophique autour des notions de Biens, de vertus et de devoirs. Quels liens une telle vision de l'éthique entretient-elle avec l'interprétation théologique de thèmes comme le Royaume de Dieu, la rédemption, la justification par la foi et la sanctification ? La concentration téléologique sur les Biens (Güterlehre) et sur le Bien suprême est-elle à comprendre aussi en un sens théologique ? Et si oui, comment penser la relation entre la dogmatique, la dialectique et l'éthique, non seulement chez Schleiermacher, mais dans le contexte moderne et postmoderne qui est le nôtre ? The relation between philosophical and theological ethics is at the centre of the thought of F. D. Schleiermacher (1768-1834). Proposing an original conception of reason in its connection to nature and to history, the author of Discourses and of The Christian Faith restructures philosophical ethics around the notions of the Good, of virtues and of duties. What connection does such a vision of ethics have with the theological interpretation of themes like the Kingdom of god, redemption, justification by faith and sanctification? Can the teleological focus on the Good fGüterlehrej andón the supreme Good be also understood theologically? If yes, how should one think of the relation between dogmatics, dialectics and ethics, not only in Schleiermacher, but in the modern and postmodern context of our age?
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44360579 journal-article-10.2307_44360579.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: LA SUBVERSION DE L'ÉVANGILE
Publisher: PCL PRESSES CENTRALES SA
Issue: i40182183
Date: 1 1, 2012
Author(s): Chalamet Christophe
Abstract: Dans cette leçon inaugurale, l'auteur se penche sur l'Évangile, compris au sens large de «promesse», comme objet et comme source de subversion. Deux textes bibliques illustrent chacun de ces deux aspects : le livre de Job et la parabole matthéenne des ouvriers de la onzième heure (Mt 20, 1-16). Une troisième et dernière partie porte sur la relation entre révélation et mystère. Le style oral a été en partie conservé. In this inaugural lecture, delivered on September 24, 2012 at the Faculty of Theology of the University of Geneva, the author develops the theme of the Gospel — understood broadly as «promise» — as both the object and subject of subversion. Two biblical texts are taken as illustrations of these two aspects: the book of Job and Matthew's parable of the vineyard workers of the eleventh hour (Mt 20:1-16). A third and final part focuses on the relation between revelation and mystery. The original style of the lecture has been partly maintained.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44360666 journal-article-10.2307_44360666.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: «UNE THÉOLOGIE INSCRITE DANS LES OPPOSITIONS DE LA VIE». AUTOUR DE LA FIGURE DE GERHARD EBELING (1912-2001): Introduction
Publisher: PCL PRESSES CENTRALES SA
Issue: i40182185
Date: 1 1, 2012
Author(s): Bühler Pierre
Abstract: «Répondre de la foi dans la rencontre avec la pensée de M.Heidegger. Thèse concernant la relation entre philosophie et théologie», RThPh 133, 2001, p. 125-130.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44360702 journal-article-10.2307_44360702.xml

Journal Title: Revue de Théologie et de Philosophie
Article Title: HEGEL ET LEVINAS: AUTRE ALTÉRITÉ, AUTRE DANGER
Publisher: PCL PRESSES CENTRALES SA
Issue: i40182200
Date: 1 1, 2011
Author(s): Pagès Claire
Abstract: Où situer le danger ? Qui court un risque et qui le fait courir à qui ? Il s'agit de présenter deux analyses inverses de la notion de danger. Leur originalité tient au fait qu'il ne semble pas y avoir pour elles d'équité ou de réciprocité dans le danger: la menace vient exclusivement d'un côté de la relation. Pour Hegel, c'est le moi qui est l'objet de menaces. L'auteur de ces menaces est toujours l'autre, celui que je ne suis pas, et c'est précisément son altérité qui en fait une puissance dont je peux craindre la violence. C'est pourquoi la vérité – et la sécurité – se trouve toujours du côté de la réduction de la transcendance de l'autre. Pour cette raison, Levinas affirme qu'il n'y a pas d'autre dans la philosophie de Hegel, absence qu'il analyse justement comme un danger: c'est l'autre qui court un risque, et la menace vient de moi. La menace n'émane plus de l'étrangeté de l'autre, mais au contraire de la suppression de cette étrangeté. Ce qu'il est à craindre est, pour Hegel, que l'autre mette la main sur moi, et, pour Levinas, que je mette la main sur l'autre. Where is the danger? Who is at risk and who is a menace to whom? This article presents two opposite analyses of the notion of danger. Their originality lies in the fact that there seems to be no fairness or reciprocity in danger: the threat comes exclusively from one side of the relationship. For Hegel, oneself is always the object of threats. The source of these threats is always the other person, the one I am not, and it is precisely the other's alterity which is a force whose violence I should fear. That is why truth - and security – are always to be found in reducing the transcendence of the other. For this reason, Levinas claims that there is not an other in the philosophy of Hegel, an absence which he analyses as a danger; it's the other who is at risk, and the threat comes from me. The threat no longer emanates from the strangeness of the other, but, on the contrary, from the suppression of this ~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44361054 journal-article-10.2307_44361054.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: L'ICÔNE-PAROLE INCRÉÉE: ESSAI DE THÉOLOGIE TRINITAIRE SELON L'ORDRE DU LANGAGE
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40184945
Date: 7 1, 1984
Author(s): Labbé Yves
Abstract: M.-J. Baudinet, « La relation iconique à Byzance au ix« siècle d'après Nicéphore le Patriarche ; un destin de l'aristotélisme », in Les Études Philosophiques, 1978, p. 91 et 98.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44407491 journal-article-10.2307_44407491.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: SPIRITUALISME ET PHILOSOPHIE RÉFLEXIVE
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40184972
Date: 1 1, 1990
Author(s): Varet Gilbert
Abstract: La relation entre spiritualisme et philosophie réflexive peut donner lieu à deux lectures inverses : ou bien la méthode reflexive trouve son fondement dans la reconnaissance de la réalité de l'esprit, ou bien c'est la pratique réflexive qui autorise et au besoin contrôle la portée des affirmations spiritualistes. L'article se situe dans cette seconde lignée. La précession de l'être par l'être qui définit la condition de la conscience ne légitime aucune intuition de l'Absolu, mais bien une affirmation ontologique originaire. L'âme, c'est la passion d'intériorité de cette auto-affirmation manifestante. Quant à l'Esprit, troisième dimension de l'être, c'est un Advenir éthique qui n'est en acte qu'à travers le monde des êtres, dans la rencontre réflexive multilatérale des consciences. The relationship between spiritualism and philosophical reflexivity can be seen in one of two ways: either a recognition of the reality of the spirit gave rise to the reflexive concept, or the practice of reflexivity came first and widened the scope of spiritual affirmations, controlling them when necessary. The article favours the latter view. The ability of a being to form a judgment about itself, and thus create a conscience, does not justify any conclusion about an Absolute, being on the contrary one of the basic statements of ontology. The soul is the result of this active self-judgment emerging from its seclusion. As for the spirit, the third component of the being, this is an ethical by-product which only comes into play through the world of beings, in the multilateral reflexive meeting of consciences.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44407987 journal-article-10.2307_44407987.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: BULLETIN DE THÉOLOGIE: THÉOLOGIE DE LA CRÉATION. SCIENCES ET THÉOLOGIE
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40184995
Date: 1 1, 1996
Author(s): Renouard D.
Abstract: J. Polkinghorne, Reason and Reality. The Relation between Science and Theo- logy. London, SPCK, 1991 ; 13,5 × 21,5, 120 p.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44408369 journal-article-10.2307_44408369.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: L'HERMÉNEUTIQUE DU TÉMOIGNAGE EN PHILOSOPHIE: LITTÉRATURE, MYTHE ET BIBLE
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40184999
Date: 1 1, 1997
Author(s): Mies Françoise
Abstract: L'étude se propose de montrer le bien-fondé et la fécondité de l'herméneutique du témoignage en philosophie en interrogeant l'un des problèmes fondamentaux que pose cette pratique, celui du rapport entre singularité et universalité, et ce dans trois champs relevant de la littérature : la littérature au sens large, les mythes littéraires et la Bible. L'étude de la notion de témoignage et de ses déplacements sémantiques dans le témoignage littéraire est inspirée de la philosophie de Paul Ricœur. Les exemples analysés sont ceux du mythe de Faust et de la figure de Job. This study endeavours to show that the hermeneutics of witness in philosophy are indeed well grounded and fecund, by inquiring into one of the essential problems of this practice : that of the relation of the singular to the universal. Three areas relating to literature are broached : literature in a wide sense, myth literature, and the Bible. This study of the idea of witness and its semantic fluctuations in witness literature is inspired by Paul Ricceur's philosophy. The examples analysed here are the Faust myth and the character Job.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44408419 journal-article-10.2307_44408419.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: JEAN NABERT ET LES PHILOSOPHIES DE LA RÉFLEXION: UN BREF REPÉRAGE
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40185012
Date: 7 1, 2000
Author(s): Quelquejeu Bernard
Abstract: Cette brève contribution propose un repérage sommaire de la philosophie de Jean Nabert par rapport à quelques-uns des courants qui traversent le champ de la philosophie contemporaine. Pour ce faire, elle utilise un article de Nabert paru en 1957 dans l'Encyclopédie Française, dans lequel l'A. se livre à une caractérisation de sa philosophie au sein de la tradition française de la philosophie réflexive. The purpose of this short contribution is to get a summary view of Jean Nabert's philosophy in relation to some of the currents that mark contemporary philosophy. The basis for this contribution is an article that Nabert published in 1957 in the Encyclopédie Française in which the author describes his own philosophy within the frame of French tradition of reflexive philosophy.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44408632 journal-article-10.2307_44408632.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: LE JUGEMENT DE VALEUR: CRÉATION ÉTHIQUE ET PLURALITÉ
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40185012
Date: 7 1, 2000
Author(s): Robilliard Stéphane
Abstract: Le jugement de valeur est étudié par Nabert dans les Éléments pour une éthique. Il se situe à l'articulation de la compréhension de soi, de l'affirmation originaire et de la régénération. Pensé comme expression d'un acte originaire et non comme participation à l'être, il permet de lier réflexion, création et pluralité. Cette perspective métaphysique, soutenue par une philosophie réflexive de la conscience, suscite une perspective critique par rapport aux théories substantialistes (Scheler, Spaemann) ou procédurales (Habermas, Renaut) de la valeur. Si la valeur est promotion d'existence, les prédicats négatifs donnent forme à l'acte de protestation contre le mal, l'injustifiable. Jean Nabert studies the judgment of value in his Éléments pour une éthique. He himself is situated at the crossroads of the comprehension of self, original affirmation, and regeneration. Seen as the expression of an originating act and not as a participation in being, it can tie together reflexion, creation and plurality. This metaphysical perspective sustained by a reflexive philosophy of conscience invites a critical perspective in relation to substantialist (Scheler, Spaemann) or procedural (Habermas, Renaut) theories of value. If value is promotion of existence, then negative predicates give form to the act of protest against evil, the unjustifiable.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44408633 journal-article-10.2307_44408633.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: LA MÉDIATION DE JÉSUS-CHRIST: LES PROPOSITIONS DE CHRISTIAN DUQUOC DANS "L'UNIQUE CHRIST. LA SYMPHONIE DIFFÉRÉE"
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40185023
Date: 6 1, 2003
Author(s): Rey Bernard
Abstract: Cette Note présente l'ouvrage de Christian Duquoc, intitulé L'unique Christ. La symphonie différée, en en suivant le déroulement et en se montrant particulièrement attentif à son apport christologique. L'approche ne se limite pas à la question de la médiation unique du Christ. Elle aborde aussi le rapport du Christ à l'histoire et au cosmos, le sens de la mission de l'Église, sa relation au judaïsme, la signification du salut et la façon de l'envisager dans le cadre d'une pluralité des religions. Au long de sa présentation, l'auteur de cette Note montre que la théologie développée dans cet ouvrage se trouvait déjà largement amorcée dans les précédents travaux de Duquoc. This Note introduces the work of Christian Duquoc, entitled L'unique Christ. La symphonie différée, surveying its development and paying particular attention to its Christological contribution. Its approach is not limited to the question of Christ's unique mediation. It takes up as well Christ's relation to history and to the cosmos, the meaning of the Church's mission, its relation to Judaism, its signification of salvation, and the way of envisaging it within the setting of a plurality of religions. During the course of his presentation, the author of this Note shows that the theology developed in this work was largely initiated in Duquoc's earlier works.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44408775 journal-article-10.2307_44408775.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: PHÉNOMÉNOLOGIE HERMÉNEUTIQUE ET PHILOSOPHIE DES SCIENCES: LA THÉORIE RICŒURIENNE DU TEXTE PEUT-ELLE AIDER À PENSER LA CONSTRUCTION DES CONCEPTS EN PHYSIQUE?
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40185091
Date: 12 1, 2005
Author(s): Harada Masaki
Abstract: P. Ricœur établit une relation méthodologique entre l'épistémologie et la phénoménologie herméneutique, en considérant l'épistémologie comme une médiation entre la phénoménologie et l'herméneutique. Cette considération de l'épistémologie en tant que médiation est profondément liée à la notion spécifique de « texte » chez P. Ricœur. Cet article montre que même si la philosophie de Ricœur ne traite pas de l'épistémologie des sciences de la nature, celle-ci peut être approfondie par une phénoménologie herméneutique : la phénoménologie éclaire la naissance du réseau conceptuel d'une théorie; l'épistémologie éclaire sa structure intérieure; l'herméneutique éclaire son interprétation et la liaison avec la réalité physique. P. Ricœur establishes a methodological relationship between epistemology and hermeneutical phenomenology, considering epistemology as mediation between phenomenology and hermeneutics. Ricœur's consideration of epistemology as mediation is profoundly related to his specific notion of text. This paper shows that even if Ricœur's philosophy does not refer to the epistemology of natural sciences, the latter can be deepened by hermeneutical phenomenology : phenomenology clarifies the birth of a conceptual network of a theory; epistemology clarifies its internal structure; hermeneutics clarifies its interpretation and its relation with physical reality.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44410220 journal-article-10.2307_44410220.xml

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques

Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN

Journal Title: Revue des Sciences philosophiques et théologiques
Article Title: BULLETIN DE PHILOSOPHIE DE LA RELIGION
Publisher: LIBRAIRIE PHILOSOPHIQUE J. VRIN
Issue: i40185260
Date: 1 1, 1953
Author(s): Léonard A.
Abstract: R. Otto, Le Sacré. L'élément non-ralionnel dans l'idée du divin et sa relation avec le rationnel. Paris, Payot, 1949 ; 22 × 14, 235 pp.

Journal Title: Historical Social Research / Historische Sozialforschung
Article Title: From Public Participation to Place-Based Resistance. Environmental Critique and Modes of Valuation in the Struggles against the Expansion of the Malpensa Airport
Publisher: GESIS - Leibniz Institute for the Social Sciences
Issue: i40185962
Date: 1 1, 2017
Author(s): Centemeri Laura
Abstract: Through an analysis of the 40-year history of conflicts triggered by the repeated attempts to expand the Malpensa airport in northern Italy, this paper seeks to show the heuristic strength of using the concept of modes of valuation of the environment to discuss the transformations of environmental critique over time in their relation to social change. I argue that, beyond empirical specifics, the trajectory witnessed in this case – from public participation to place-based resistance – reflects more generalized dynamics that can be found in many other conflicts over large infrastructural projects in contemporary Europe. The article is organized as follows: in the first section I briefly introduce the concept of modes of valuation of the environment, which is inspired by recent work in pragmatic sociology. In particular, I distinguish between universal, local, and emplaced modes of valuation. In the second and third sections I provide an analysis of the struggles against the Malpensa airport expansion from 1970 to 2014. Here, I distinguish three phases of mobilization, which I discuss in terms of the transformations that can be observed in the arguments that actors develop to fight or support the airport expansion. I argue that these transformations are articulated not only with changing action repertoires but also with evolving social and sociotechnical imaginarles that convey specific understandings of the environment as a matter of political concern. This analysis shows that, far from being simply a case of citizens' resistance to change, the mobilization against the Malpensa airport has contributed to producing the cultural basis of an increased collective reflexivity about the many values that the environment takes on among community members in the airport region. In the final section I discuss some hypotheses concerning what modes of valuation of the environment reveal about the emergence of a new radicalism in environmental struggles.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/44425364 journal-article-10.2307_44425364.xml

Journal Title: Comparative Studies in Society and History
Article Title: Creole Publics: Language, Cultural Citizenship, and the Spread of the Nation in Mauritius
Publisher: Cambridge University Press
Issue: i405056
Date: 10 1, 2004
Author(s): Woolard Patrick
Abstract: Anderson, the possibility for persons to experience themselves as members of a national community also depended on a shift towards "empty, homogeneous" time, which was in turn motivated through the growing popularity of the novel as a literary genre. Anderson argues that the narrative structure of the novel rests on a yardstick of empty, homogeneous time, which is lin- early progressing, divisible into an infinite number of abstract, equivalent units, and independent from any particular locale. Disparate characters in a novel, who may be in different locations and completely unaware of the presence of certain other characters, and their actions in the unfold- ing plot can be placed in relation to each other by virtue of temporal simultaneity on such an axis of empty, homogeneous time. This narrative and temporal structuring particular to the literary genre of the novel provides an analogy to the way in which persons imagine themselves as progressing through history together in a national community, knowing that they exist together with other co-nationals in a synchronic cross-section of time (1991: 25-26)
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/4497713 journal-article-10.2307_4497713.xml

Journal Title: Medical Anthropology Quarterly
Article Title: The Meaning of the Present: Hope and Foreclosure in Narrations about People with Severe Brain Damage
Publisher: American Anthropological Association
Issue: i405180
Date: 9 1, 1998
Author(s): van DongenAbstract: In this article, I consider narratives told within a clinical setting. I argue that personnel in a day center for people with acquired brain damage are constantly involved in narrating about the disabled participants. The negotiation of who the participant is, and foremost will be, is in constant negotiation in regard to issues of hope. I further argue that hope is a meaning-making process and, as such, it has been defined as crucially connected to time. Hope has been said to enable a connection between the present and the future, because action taken in the present could bring about (positive) change in the future. However, I show that hope, in relation to narratives told about people with severe disabilities that are considered "incurable," must be understood within a realm of narrative foreclosure. Time seems to have lost the openness of its horizon for these people, and a narrative that tells of immediacy rather than chronology is created, resulting in hope being established within the present.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/4499735 journal-article-10.2307_4499735.xml

Journal Title: PMLA
Article Title: Falstaff as Parodist and Perhaps Holy Fool
Publisher: Modern Language Association of America
Issue: i219705
Date: 1 1, 1972
Author(s): Sittler Roy
Abstract: Starting with Raglan's suggestion that Falstaff may be a "holy fool" and with Auden's belief that he is a comic symbol of charity, this essay explores the medieval tradition of wise fool, and especially Falstaff's always canny use of biblical allusion. His various jests, if read in relation to the political action of the main plot, reveal him as characterizing England's time of day and parodying the unchristian behavior of Hotspur, Henry, and Hal. By the time he dies mumbling Psalm xxiii to an uncomprehending Nell Quickly, there have accumulated many hints that he is, in fact, a candle to his age, a professional Fool with the heart of a faithful Lazarus, and destined to join Mowbray in Abraham's bosom. The merriment for which readers have found him lovable amid his masquerades of vice has its mysterious basis in his covertly Christian understanding of England's neo-Roman Caesars.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/461346 journal-article-10.2307_461346.xml

Journal Title: Chinese Literature: Essays, Articles, Reviews (CLEAR)
Article Title: Reading Qian Zhongshu's "God's Dream" as a Postmodern Text
Publisher: CLEAR
Issue: i221614
Date: 12 1, 1993
Author(s): Ning Sheng-Tai
Abstract: Robbe-Grillet ..." ("The Post- modern Weltanschauung and its Relation with Modernism: An Introductory Survey," Approaching Postmod- ernism, eds. Douwe Fokkema & Hans Bertens [Amsterdam / Philadelphia: Benjamin, 1986], 19) Robbe-Grillet The Postmodern Weltanschauung and its Relation with Modernism: An Introductory Survey 19 Approaching Postmodernism 1986

Journal Title: Alif: Journal of Comparative Poetics
Article Title: أسطورة الخلق في شرق أفريقيا / The Myth of Creation in East Africa
Publisher: American University in Cairo. Department of English and Comparative Literature
Issue: i222581
Date: 1 1, 1967
Author(s): Ricoeur Nabila
Abstract: The "Myth of Creation" in its East African formulation is the central chapter in a book entitled, The Sacred Meadows, by an Egyptian anthropologist who did his field work in the early seventies among the Lamu community in Kenya on the shores of the Indian Ocean. The translator, in her own introduction to the translation, presents the outline of the book and provides the geographical and cultural context of the community in question. The author, in this translated chapter, sets out by exposing his theoretical position which combines both Structuralism and Functionalism. Insights from Claude Lévi-Strauss and Bronislaw Malinowski as well as those of Paul Ricoeur and Victor Turner join to develop the author's notion of myth and its symbolic mode. Then the text of the myth, in its Lamuan formulation, is narrated, followed by a close reading and analysis of its binary oppositions, mediating terms, and the underlying existential contradiction at its crux. Angels, jinn, light, fire, earth, wind, water, Adam, Eve, Cain, Abel, Satan, serpent, etc. are the agents of this sacred narrative and cosmic drama. The textual unfolding of the myth is followed by an analysis, which makes use of the structural method and explores the semantic connotations of Swahili words and idioms to explain the logic of the symbolic exchange and the rigor of thought. The themes of unity and multiplicity and their different combinations are delineated in this analysis and the repetitions and their relation to transcendence are explained.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/521626 journal-article-10.2307_521626.xml

Journal Title: Alif: Journal of Comparative Poetics
Article Title: ﺗﻄﻮّﺭ ﺍﻟﻨﻈﺮﻳﺔ ﺍﻷﺩﺑّﻴﺔ / The Evolution of Literary Theory
Publisher: American University in Cairo. Department of English and Comparative Literature
Issue: i222566
Date: 4 1, 1974
Author(s): Culler ﻣﻬﺎ ﺟﻼﻝ
Abstract: «At the basis of the literary act is a consciousness of language. Whether or not the writer is given to abstract reflexion, there is in literature itself a metaliterary dimension.» In his article on the Evolution of Literary Theory, Tzvetan Todorov examines the relation between the «discourse on Literature» and the object of that discourse: literature. Whereas exegesis concerns itself with the Elucidation and explanation of an historically given object, theory itself constitutes its object. Theory then is in turn seen to be historically informed. From the Poetics of Aristotle, through the medieval hermeneuts, the Renaissance concern with genres, Todorov traces the development of the theoretical discourse which proposes literature as its object. Only in the romantic period is a theory of literature, in the strict sense, elaborated. In the 20th century this theory is further influenced by other emergent disciplines :Marxism, psychoanalysis etc. The final pages of Todorov's paper consider in detail the impact of structuralism, particularly in France, on the literary theoretical discourse. He concludes with reference to the changes taking place currently. According to Todorov, it is in the «idea of genre» that the «transformation will take place.»
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/521871 journal-article-10.2307_521871.xml

Journal Title: The British Journal of Sociology
Article Title: Freud, Psychoanalysis, and Sociology: Some Observations on the Sociological Analysis of the Individual
Publisher: Routledge and Kegan Paul Ltd. For the London School of Economics
Issue: i224978
Date: 12 1, 1978
Author(s): Adorno Robert
Abstract: This paper is an advocacy for the employment of psychoanalytical concepts within sociological theorizing about the individual. Through an exposition of Freud's views on the development of intra-psychic structure and a critique of Parson's reduction of psychoanalysis to a branch of learning theory, I attempt to show that the sociological approach to the individual is implicitly behavioural and imprisoned in a series of assumptions which, among other things, treats subjectivity as epiphenomenal and identity as an unmediated reflection of some external reality. In contrast, psychoanalysis presents to us a picture of the individual as flawed and ambivalent in his relation to society, formed by but at odds with the demands of culture. In particular, the psychoanalytic concept of identification reveals that the acquisition of identity is a hard-won achievement marked by the renunciation of lost and forbidden objects. I argue, following Freud and Lacan, that the ego, far from being an agency of reason, somehow directly 'plugged into' reality, constitutes itself in the fantasied image of another and that the quality of this identification crucially affects the way the world is experienced and believed by the individual. This argument is elaborated through a discussion of Peter Berger's remarks on the social causes of identity crisis which, when set against the work of object-relations theorists on those suffering from disturbances of identity such as, for example, schizoid personalities, are shown to be both superficial and misleading. I conclude the paper by arguing that while psychoanalysis can enhance our understanding of the way in which the individual is formed by and through culture it also cautions us against making simple generalizations about the impact of culture upon the person, showing that the individual never submits himself unequivocally to its demands and interdicts.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/589361 journal-article-10.2307_589361.xml

Journal Title: Journal of the American Oriental Society
Article Title: Mīmāṃsā and the Problem of History in Traditional India
Publisher: American Oriental Society
Issue: i225333
Date: 12 1, 1986
Author(s): Feenberg Sheldon
Abstract: W. Den Boer, "Graeco-Roman Historiography in its Relation to Biblical and Modern Thinking" (History and Theory7 [1968]: 60-75) 10.2307/2504266 60
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/604085 journal-article-10.2307_604085.xml

Journal Title: American Anthropologist
Article Title: Twice-Born, Once Conceived: Meaning Construction and Cultural Cognition
Publisher: American Anthropological Association
Issue: i227551
Date: 3 1, 1933
Author(s): Williamson Bradd
Abstract: Cultural cognition is the product of two different sorts of meaning: (a) the (objective) semiotic organization of cultural texts or models, and (b) the (subjective) processes of meaning construction through which cultural symbols become available to consciousness as "experience." This article proposes a way to bridge these two kinds of meaning by considering how cultural knowledge is grounded in sensory experience. Several cognitive processes (schematization, synesthesia, secondary intersubjectivity) are proposed for linking the objectively available schemata found in cultural practices and the processes of meaning construction by which individuals appropriate symbols to consciousness. The nature of the relation between public symbols and individual experience is discussed in relation to a number of current issues in post-structuralist culture theory.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/681471 journal-article-10.2307_681471.xml

Journal Title: Canadian Journal of Education / Revue canadienne de l'éducation
Article Title:
Publisher: University of Toronto Press
Issue: canajeducrevucan.33.issue-4
Date: February 1, 2010
Author(s): Haig-Brown Celia
Abstract: Dans cet article, l'auteure pose la question suivante: « Quelle est la relation entre l'appropriation de la pensée autochtone et ce qu'on pourrait appeler l' apprentissage en profondeurbasé sur des années d'expérience en éducation dans des contextes autochtones? » Après avoir analysé les divers sens attribués à la notion d'appropriation culturelle, l'auteure présente des textes de Gee sur les discours secondaires, de Foucault sur la production du discours et de Wertsch sur les structures profondes du discours et fait le lien avec des expériences décisives sur le terrain tirées d'années de recherche et d'enseignement. Gardant au fond de l'espoir, l'auteure conclut l'article en présentant le protocole d'appropriation culturelle recommandé par des universitaires autochtones lors de l'utilisation de savoirs autochtones par des personnes nonautochtones dans des contextes pédagogiques.

Journal Title: Canadian Journal of Sociology / Cahiers canadiens de sociologie
Article Title: Respect for privacy and data protection not the same thing
Publisher: Springer Verlag
Issue: canajsocicahican.37.issue-3
Date: August 30, 2010
Author(s): Yeo Michael
Abstract: Résumé. L'un des principaux problèmes dans la controverse entourant le recensement détaillé concernait la relation entre la science et la politique. En analysant les arguments et les hypothèses sous-jacentes de quatre interventions influentes et exemplaires faites au nom de la science, cet article rend un constat normatif de cette relation. Il nuance les idéaux protecteurs de la science que les critiques ont invoqués et avance que de telles ressources conceptuelles sont nécessaires pour protéger la science d'un empiètement politique indu. Cependant, dans leur zèle à défendre les droits de la science, les critiques en ont réclamé plus que nécessaire, ce qui a occulté la dimension de la valeur des décisions politiques et n'a pas respecté le rôle de la politique en tant que point légitime de prise de décision sur les questions de valeur. Un constat normatif adéquat de la relation entre la science et la politique dans la politique gouvernementale doit non seulement protéger la science contre la politique, mais aussi la politique contre la science.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/canajsocicahican.37.3.295 journal-article-10.2307_canajsocicahican.37.3.295.xml

Journal Title: Journal of Higher Education in Africa / Revue de l'enseignement supérieur en Afrique
Article Title: ‘The Virgin of Guadalupe: A Mexican National Symbol’
Publisher: Routledge
Issue: jhigheducafri.8.issue-2
Date: October 1, 1958
Author(s): Macdonald Helen M.
Abstract: This paper emerges out of an ethnographic study conducted at the University of Cape Town that explored the dynamics of an intervention providing a ‘safe space’ for university staff to engage in alternative ways with South Africa's apartheid past, the university's institutional culture and with each other. This paper focuses on the social politics that arose between the intervention, its participants and imagined non-participants in relation to the university's ‘transformation’ vision. The interventionist intention was reworked by participants at a ground level into key symbols by which participants shaped the patterns of their behaviours and gave meaning to their experiences. Utilising Ortner's (1973) model for recognising and using key symbols, I argue that ‘transformation’ and ‘safe space’ are elaboratingsymbols in that they have conceptual and action elaborating power. These elaborating symbols operate in relay with a kind of logic that ‘crystallises commitment’ from participants to the intervention in an emotionally powerful and relatively undifferentiated manner. In so doing, they render the intervention a ‘summarising’ symbol capable of expressing what their experience means to them as an imagined community in relation to others.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/jhigheducafri.8.2.73 journal-article-10.2307_jhigheducafri.8.2.73.xml

Journal Title: Journal of Folklore Research: An International Journal of Folklore and Ethnomusicology
Article Title: “Introduction.”
Publisher: Indiana University Press
Issue: jfolkrese.51.issue-1
Date: 1 1, 1988
Author(s): Sandell David P.
Abstract: This article treats Mexican retablos(devotional paintings) in relation to people's actions. Retablos serve as a basis for seeing, talking about, and interpreting events born from oppressive, modern conditions. Actions and artful representation indicate, respectively, proximity to reality, from near to far—a difference that outlines a space for aesthetic production. I argue that retablos contribute to an aesthetic that orients the senses and the mind against oppressive conditions and toward a positive vision of what the world might be.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.2979/jfolkrese.51.1.13 journal-article-10.2979_jfolkrese.51.1.13.xml

Journal Title: Comparative Literature Studies
Article Title: Poetry Is Theft
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: complitstudies.51.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2014
Abstract: Hayes frequently uses recombination and assiduously designed constraints to link his poems to those of African American women poets who have preceded him. In Hip Logic, he includes as an epigraph a poem “made up of whole and partial lines in the index (underW) ofThe Collected Poems of.”audre lorde The collection also includes a sonnet entirely made up of the line “We sliced the watermelon into smiles” repeated fourteen times, and several odes. The bulk of the book is made up of a series of poems titled “A Gram of &S,” based on the daily word game found in the puzzle section of newspapers. Hayes explains in a note, “I end each line with one of the eleven words derived from the title word, while abiding by the other rules of the game: 1. Words must be derived from four or more letters. 2. Words that acquire four letters by the addition of ‘s,’ such as ‘bats’ or ‘dies’ are not used. 3. Only one form of a verb is used.”91 In a more recent collection titled92 Lighthead, Hayes also uses constraints. Reading just the end words of “The Golden Shovel” inLightheadgives the entirety of Gwendolyn Brooks's poem “We Real Cool”: When I am so small Da's sock covers my arm, we Cruise at twilight until we find the place the real Brooks's poem has been literally re-authored, as has Elizabeth Alexander's “Ladders,” which emerges in the end words of Hayes' poem “The Last Train to Africa”Men lean, bloodshot and translucent with cool. 93 in precisely the same way. Homage and lineage are inscribed directly into Hayes's poems, so that the reader cannot read one without the other. This incorporation of the precursor is more thoroughgoing than an onomastic reference or dedication: it literally reproduces the precursor poem. As Hayes's new poem circulates, Brooks's ~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/complitstudies.51.1.0018 journal-article-10.5325_complitstudies.51.1.0018.xml

Journal Title: The F. Scott Fitzgerald Review
Article Title: “Nature and Optics in the Great Gatsby.”
Publisher: Penguin
Issue: fscotfitzrevi.12.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 1989
Author(s): Salmose Niklas
Abstract: Another change is that the second part of the novel is more inclined to use close-ups rather than the inclusive seductive tracking, or “zooming” shots of the first part, thus entering into a more psychological tensional discourse. When Nick finds Gatsby in the pool, the camera eye does not change focal lengths from long shot to close-up in order to create a sense of awe, but instead moves closely between certain symbols: The emotional response to this stylistic close-up technique differs radically from the one of motion that worked so inclusively in the first part. Since Gatsby lies dead in the pool, there is no mystery anymore. The movement of the camera eye from one image to another slows down the duration of the scene drastically. Fitzgerald's literary technique “resembles filmmakers’ metaphorical use of the moving camera as a consumer of time,” Kundu suggests. This implies that Gatsby “is a victim not only of his impossible dream, but also of time's cruel prodigality, indeed, of the tragic flux and mutability of life itself” (Kundu 42). It also contradicts the novel's relation to movement in general; Berman describes the motion of the leaves as “moving, but going nowhere” (44).There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water. (162)
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/fscotfitzrevi.12.1.0067 journal-article-10.5325_fscotfitzrevi.12.1.0067.xml

Journal Title: Interdisciplinary Literary Studies
Article Title: “History and Tragedy.”
Publisher: Harper and Row
Issue: intelitestud.16.2.issue-2
Date: 9 1, 1971
Author(s): Eze Chielozona
Abstract: Remembering is a function of the meaning-making process after the emptiness of loss. Spelder and Strickland suggest that “grief is the emotional response to bereavement, to the event of loss” (as qtd. in DuBose, 368). The theologian Todd J. DuBose explains that “grief gazes at an ever-receding present as it moves further and further into the past. The immediate reaction often involves bargaining for a reversal of the loss, denial, anger, shock, anguish, distress, sadness” (368). These reactions are the body's means of trying to make sense of the world in the wake of the emptiness created by bereavement. Interpreting Drew Leder and Maurice Merleau-Ponty's notion of chiasmic structure of the body, DuBose explains that the body realizes its existence only in relation to other bodies. It touches because it is being touched. Other bodies make ours perceptible. The disappearance of these other bodies in death is, in tune with the chiasmic structure of bodily existence, the disappearance of our own bodies. We experience that disappearance as pain, grief, sorrow. These manifestations of pain are, indeed, the ways our bodies adjust to vacuum and fill it with meaning. For DuBose, “meaning-making processes, which appearto be immaterial processes, are embodied phenomena. Reflection, perception, feeling, language, even logic make sense only through the influx of the body's ‘reading’ of space, time, action, and sensation” (370).
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/intelitestud.16.2.0282 journal-article-10.5325_intelitestud.16.2.0282.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: American Continental Philosophy in the Making:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: In relation to these frustrating circumstances, however, I benefited in still another way from the early SPEP meetings. Had I been simply caught between my friends and teachers at Illinois and Northwestern, on the one hand, and the larger hostile culture of the philosophical mainstream, on the other, I might well have chosen a career of either speaking mostly to my own kind or becoming a professional critic. But in the diversity of those early meetings, I also found that it was hard to define just what “my own kind” was supposed to be. For me, an important fact about our theoretically underorganized little band is that we ourselves sometimes seemed only marginally better than the tradition at putting our passions into proper words. The difference, of course, is that many of us knew this. The fact that we continued to compromise our own efforts to be phenomenological simply encouraged us to be more phenomenological.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0108 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0108.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: The Plight of Ethics
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Joining hyperbolic ethics with psychoanalysis, then, we might begin to forge ethics and politics in a necessary but tense relation, as the place where we find ourselves: this is our plight as social creatures living together with others. Navigating between Kant's too-easy unification of ethics and politics through universal moral law based on duty, on the one hand, and Levinas's radical separation of the two based on the singularity of infinite ethical repsonsiblity, on the other, let's say that social subjectivity is the thin membrane stretched between infinite ethical responsibility and finite political action. And its depth is the thickness of the flesh in embodied relations with others. Subjectivity is response to others and the environment that binds us to them, on the one hand; and agency is response to social historical situations, or subject positions, that binds us to the language and culture into which we are born—for better or worse—on the other (see Oliver 2001,2004). Subjective agency is forged through this pledge or bond between politics and ethics made possible, even necessary, by our sociality; we are social embodied animals with fears and desires beyond our control, fears and desires that make love possible but also make hatred and cruelty realities that we cannot ignore. Our social subjectivity is that thin membrane and that thick embodied relationship with those around us, whether they are animal, vegetable, or mineral, human, beast, or machine—or more to the point here, whether they are friend or enemy, loved or hated, welcoming or threatening.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0118 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0118.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Phenomenology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Paceboth Brentano and Chisholm, if the I is substance and the principle of individuation, we must steer clear of saying that the unique essence is what one has and, rather, hold that the unique essence is precisely what “I” refers to and it does not refer to a property of this referent. In this case the I-substance is self-individuating, that is,per seand not individuatedper accidensor by reason of being put in relation with another. Of course, we must keep separate the phenomenological-ontological distinctions that surface among “the ‘I’” (or “my I”) as material for eidetic analysis, what the indexical “I” brings to light, and what this indexical “I” pre-reflectively presupposes for its reference. In the latter two cases we do not need individuating markers; nor do we have to do with what/who has properties but, rather, with what/who is nonsortal and referred to nonascriptively. (See below.)
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0222 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0222.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Ethics and Religion in Continental Philosophy
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Second, there is a second revolution, even more radical and directly pertinent to both ethics and religion. But not only there. The concept of inverted intentionality, an intentionality of “a wholly different type,” requires a fundamental rethinking of the phenomenological method and project. We are not as far along on this, I think, as we are on coming to terms with the first revolution. More systematic work needs to be done in thinking through the transcendence, passivity, and heteronomy implied in being seen and being addressed. Perhaps Marion has pointed in the right direction in his answer to the question: Who comes after the (Cartesian) self (transcendental ego)? The self is l'interloqué (Angesprochene), the one addressed, called out, claimed. The self is40 l'adonné, the one gifted or given over. Our task is in large measure to think out the meaning of such names for the self and to come up with others equally illuminating. For ethics and religion always concern the question, Who am I?—in relation to that which transcends me.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0333 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0333.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Introduction
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
Date: 7 1, 2014
Author(s): Steinbock Anthony
Abstract: Such vulnerability to assault raises questions of ethics that are central to the next section, entitled “Ethics and Reciprocity in Heidegger and Beauvoir.” Julie Kuhlken's article, “Heidegger and Aristotle: Action, Production, and Ethos,” considers Heidegger's practical philosophy, as expressed in his “Letter on Humanism,” in relation to his lectures on Aristotle from the 1920s. Through a discussion of Heidegger's distinctions between action and effecting and between ethics and ethos, Kuhlken argues that Heidegger's practical philosophy focuses less on ethics as it is typically understood today and more on the ancient notion of the good life. In “The Other (Woman): Limits of Knowledge in Beauvoir's Ethics of Reciprocity,” Ellie Anderson reassesses Beauvoir's ethics of reciprocity through a reading of her 1943 novel She Came to Stay. Anderson argues, against prominent readers of Beauvoir such as Penelope Deutscher and Debra Bergoffen, that central to Beauvoir's ethics is the recognition of the irreducible otherness or radical alterity of the other—and thus of a fundamental epistemic gap between self and other.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.28.3.0213 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.28.3.0213.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Is a Hermeneutic Phenomenology Wide Enough? A Ricoeurian Reply to Janicaud's
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
Date: 7 1, 2014
Author(s): Davidson Scott
Abstract: It seems to me that this provides the basis for a good answer to the question that was posed at the outset of this article, that is: “Is a hermeneutic phenomenology ‘wide open’ enough for a minimal phenomenology?” This is indeed the case. For, just as Freud's mixed discourse means that each discourse points to a discourse outside itself, the same could be said of the relation between Deleuze and phenomenology. The key here is to recognize that the nonsignifying or the impersonal is on the way to meaning and on the way to consciousness. And at the same time, phenomenological discourse necessarily points back to a nonsignifying or impersonal reality that precedes and gives rise to it. The role of a hermeneutic phenomenology is to mediate between these two discourses by traveling along this path back and forth between meaning and its becoming, following its composition and decomposition in the movement from sense to non-sense, from the impersonal to the personal, from the formless to form—and back again.26
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.28.3.0315 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.28.3.0315.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: Recovering Hyperbole:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: philrhet.45.4.issue-4
Date: 12 1, 2012
Abstract: Within this story, however, is also an errant subject. The wandering and wondering subject within the text—which is also to say beyond the text—who is “greatly astounded” (Mark 10:26) is left to wrestle with his or her subjectivity on a hermeneutical level and err toward an insight indicated through the disorienting hyperbole, for example, one's relation to God and to money as well as one's conception of the kingdom of God. Hyperbolic errancy, then, is not only a rhetorical strategy of exaggeration. To arrive at the truth by falsehood is also a mode of thought and an act of becoming, as noted by Genette and Bakhtin. The lie of hyperbole presents one with an opportunity to explore the hermeneutical possibilities for expanding one's conception of truth(s) beyond its conventional bounds.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.45.4.0406 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.45.4.0406.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: “Reading the Past against the Grain: The Shape of Memory Studies.”
Publisher: University of Chicago Press
Issue: philrhet.46.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 1998
Abstract: In Time and Narrative, Ricoeur aligns the first stage of the hermeneutic circle, mimesis1, with the function of “prefiguration.” This concept describes the way in which narratives are “emplotted” according to “a preunderstanding of the world of action” (1984, 1:54). Ricoeur explains that preunderstanding has three primary features that affect the composition of a plot: meaningful structures, symbolic resources, and temporal character. The “meaningful structures” to which he refers can also be understood as a “conceptual network” of actions, people, events, stories, and the like. Just as words in a sentence constitute the level of semantic composition, the building blocks of activity in a narrative constitute a “semantics of action.” When writing of mimesis1, Ricoeur concentrates on the resources available within the context in which the text was produced rather than on describing how texts exhibit a semantics of action. It is in this cultural context that he locates the latent possibilities for emplotting action in a narrative. The “symbolic resources” are the ingredients of emplotment in a narrative, much as nouns, verbs, and objects are the ingredients of a sentence. Which types of resources are publicly available for representing human action? What are the various formulations for embedding human action in the unfolding of time? That is, what is the “temporal character” of narratives? How are human beings within a given cultural and historical context predisposed to understand the relation of human beings and human activities to time? How is time itself conceived in the society? Each of these elements—structures, symbols, and temporality—contributes to the prefiguration of the field of understanding wherein a narrative is emplotted (1984, 1:54–64).
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.46.2.0182 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.46.2.0182.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Dilemmas and Delusions
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Wixson Christopher
Abstract: The resonance of Shaw's perspectives on health deepens in his later writings, from Back to Methuselah(1921) andThe Intelligent Woman's Guide to Socialism and Capitalism(1928) toDoctors' Delusions(1932) andFarfetched Fables(1948–50). In them, with an eye toward collective wellness, progressive growth, and enduring fitness, he promulgates interrelated theories of metabiology, socialism, despotism, and evolution. His constellation of superabundant vitality, political and metaphysical sensibilities, and practices of diet, exercise, and dress evokes a Victorian construction of healthiness, understood, according to historian Bruce Haley, as “a state of constitutional growth and development in which the bodily systems and mental faculties interoperate harmoniously under the direct motive power of vital energy or the indirect motive power of the moral will, or both. Its signs are, subjectively recognized, a sense of wholeness and unencumbered capability, and, externally recognized, the production of useful, creative labor.” For many at the time,18 mens sana in corpore sanoconceptualized the healthy body as a vivarium for intellectual and moral growth while others were more radically materialist in positing happiness and good living as dependent upon the physiological self. In any case, as Haley maintains, the “practice of analogically or metaphorically connecting [spiritual health and bodily health] was habitual in Victorian epistemology[,] … the ideal of personal health a way of grasping the proper relation between the self as a whole … and the unity of moral and physical laws which transcend the self.” If consistent with their yoking of vivacity, integrity, and volition, Shaw flipped the hierarchy that privileged the corporeal, figuring the intellectual will as the unifying and driving force in health; in his words, “it is the mind that makes the body and not the body the mind.”19 Malaise indicated deficiencies ~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0001.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Bernard Shaw and Paul Ricoeur
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Einsohn Howard Ira
Abstract: For example, Shaw could agree with Schopenhauer that the world is fundamentally Will and simultaneously reject his metaphysics of unmitigated pessimism. He could concur with Nietzsche that the Judeo-Christian God is a deceased phantom and that institutionalized religion is a repressive force but still devoutly believe in a limited and liberating divine-like creative Life Force that suffuses the cosmos and drives evolution. He could also vehemently reject Darwin in favor of Lamarck on the grounds that the former banished not only mind but hope from the universe, leaving everything to fickle chance, whereas the latter accommodated will, purpose, and effort in mapping the descent of species. And he could agree with Marx that capitalism is a pestilence and deny both the determinism inherent in dialectical materialism as well as the implication that capitalists per se are wicked. In another register, he could denounce vaccines and vivisectionists and still lobby for something like a National Health Service, staffed by professionals dedicated to keeping the nation healthy through certified medical practices, in contradistinction to the unscrupulous charlatans of the day, who exploited human misery by peddling snake oil cures. Similarly, he could chide scientists for mistaking the relation of cause and effect but praise Einstein for his discovery of the curvilinear universe. He could likewise doubt the veracity of the Bible as literal truth but cherish the redemptive dimensions of its symbols, metaphors, and parables. In this connection, he could eschew the idea that Jesus died sacrificially on the cross to expiate our sins vicariously, only to rise from the dead three days later, and at the same affirm that the Nazarene embodied, in his teachings and actions, the best roadmap we have to earthly salvation. And perhaps most important of all, he could see the ubiquity of evil yet nevertheless maintain that it was a contingent rather than a necessary fact of life—more a produ~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0133 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0133.xml

Journal Title: Style
Article Title: “The Novelist as Medium.”
Publisher: Routledge
Issue: style.35.issue-4
Date: 12 1, 2000
Author(s): Walsh Richard
Abstract: The concept of fabula, or its many near equivalents, has always been a staple of narrative theory, yet it is vulnerable to many theoretical objections. It is possible to justify a rhetorical view of the concept's pragmatic value, and so its particular relevance to fiction, but only once various flawed notions of fabula have been eliminated. Some of these relate back quite directly to its Russian Formalist roots, but others have arisen through Structuralist mediations of the concept (in the guise of such pairs as “story” and “discourse”). The inadequacies of these models are manifest in fabula's relationship to event, chronology, temporality, causality, perspective, medium, and the genesis of narrative. The concept remains valuable, however, in respect of its role in interpretation, especially in the case of fictional narrative. The rhetorical basis of this view of fabula and its relation to sujet effectively overturns the logical hierarchy of previous representational models.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/style.35.4.592 journal-article-10.5325_style.35.4.592.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Rhetorical Function of Utopia:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Marcuse's attitudes about utopia changed over the course of his career, and he remained ambivalent about the chance of realizing a utopian society. At the beginning of his career, his book Eros and Civilization(1955) defined utopia as the classic notion of an unachievable but desirable no-place outside of history, but by the end of his career, in his last book,The Aesthetic Dimension(1978), he had somewhat accepted Bloch's idea of the socialist “concrete utopia.” The emphases on quality and eros turn Marcuse's theory toward aesthetics, and as a result he favors arts and letters as vehicles for social change in the process of educating human desire. Clearly these are areas that touch on the function of rhetoric as well. Utopia for Marcuse is seen in relation to the progress of social change, and art's role is to keep alive the possibility of social and cultural transformation—the idea of utopia as a possible aim. In this way he resembles Bloch; both of them have a rhetorical role for utopian art and mediated productions of all kinds. However, Marcuse's utopia differs from Bloch's in that the present and the future are greatly separated, instead of one continually emerging from the other in an unfolding process. Utopia is a kind of natural, interpersonal eros that could sprout from the ashes of a formerly repressed society—something more chiastic than progressive, to use Mannheim's terms. In the meantime, false needs, such as those evoked through advertising, must be exposed, and true needs should be cultivated in their place. The work ethic would be replaced by a principle of receptivity and nonviolence (i.e., eros), and the highest value would be sufficiency rather than superabundance.28 29
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.1.0113 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.1.0113.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Meta-Utopian Metatext:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.2.issue-2
Date: 10 1, 2012
Abstract: However, it is not so much that Joyce is denouncing his own project; it is more that he is inscribing his critics, allowing his refutations lease to disprove his work's position—giving them enough rope to let them bind themselves ineluctably within that position. The voices of artist and critic are bound up into a Joycean harmony of contradiction (in Finnegans Wakechaos finds itself harmonious): as Finn Fordham has suggested, “the relation between Shem and Shaun is like that between two parts of his own self: the visionary artist … and the revisionary critic who chides, reproaches, denigrates, and even slanders. There is an interchangeability in these inseparable twins.” The vision can only be realized through confrontation and reconciliation with its opposite. The Utopian and the anti-Utopian (which is not the dystopian but the critique of the Utopian essential for the realization of Utopia) bring each other into being. It is the dynamic friction between them that concretizes Utopian abstraction.130
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.2.0472 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.2.0472.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Problematic of Architecture and Utopia
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.25.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2014
Abstract: As has been argued throughout this introduction, the complex relation between architecture and Utopia remains peculiarly undertheorized. In most conversations concerning the two, Utopiais, as has been suggested, shorthand for either escape or failure. The possibility that Utopia might actually offer insights into the prospect of a better world, by informing both theory and praxis, remains all but invisible within the discipline of architecture, except when confused with visionary fantasy projects destined to remain on paper or with audacious built works generally absent of a concern for architecture's fundamental social dimension.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.25.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.25.1.0001.xml
